item.title: At Least Four Dead After Tornado, Storm Batters St. Louis, Mayor Says
item.description: ST. LOUIS (AP) — At least seven people died and authorities were searching from building to building for people who were trapped or hurt after severe storms including at least one possible tornado swept through Missouri.

media:content.media:description: People survey damage after a severe storm in St. Louis on May 16.

item.title: Turkey’s Celebi Says It’s Cooperating After India Revokes Clearance
item.description: Turkish company Çelebi Aviation said on Saturday it’s “fully cooperating” with Indian authorities and adhering to regulations after its ground handling and cargo warehouse operations were suspended due to national security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Boarding stairs stand on the tarmac at Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport, operated by Adani Group, in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, May 22, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, the conglomerate controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc. Photographer: Sumit Dayal/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Faces Call From Her Local Party to Abandon Disability Cuts
item.description: Rachel Reeves's local Labour party will demand that the Chancellor abandons her plans to cut disability benefits.

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, during a news conference following her presentation of the Spring Statement in London, UK, on Wednesday, March 26, 2025. Reeves clawed back £14 billion ($18 billion) worth of fiscal room with cuts to welfare and government spending, after the UK’s growth forecast for the current year was cut in half.

item.title: Abrego Garcia Judge Frustrated at US Not Answering Questions
item.description: A federal judge repeatedly expressed frustration Friday at the Trump administration’s failure to answer her questions about what it is doing to facilitate the return of a Maryland resident wrongly deported to a notorious prison in his native El Salvador.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Willmer, David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A picture of Kilmar Abrego Garcia during a news conference to discuss Abrego Garcia's arrest and deportation d at Cannon House Office Building on April 9, 2025 in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump Expects to Meet With Putin to ‘Make a Deal’ to End War
item.description: President Donald Trump predicted he would probably meet with Russian leader Vladimir Putin, suggesting that he saw a potential face-to-face encounter as the only way to broker an end to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump, center, speaks during the US-UAE Investment Forum in Abu Dhabi on May 16. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images

item.title: White House Criticizes Moody’s Downgrade to US Credit Rating
item.description: The White House on Friday assailed a decision by Moody’s Ratings to lower the US credit rating, casting it as a political decision.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Crews hang an American flag prior to a campaign event with US Vice President Kamala Harris, not pictured, at the Carrie Blast Furnaces National Historic Landmark in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US, on Monday, Nov. 4, 2024. Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are separated by the narrowest of margins in polls, which show Tuesday's election is a coin flip, and by a chasm in their future vision for the world's premier economic and military power. Photographer: Michael Rayne Swensen/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says He’s Willing to Travel to China for Xi Meeting
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he would be willing to travel to China to speak with Xi Jinping about foreign policy and economic issues.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI and Michele Spatari/Bloomberg

item.title: Indian Companies, Consumers Snub Pakistan and Its Allies
item.description: A growing number of Indian merchants, companies, and consumers are cutting business ties with Pakistan and some of its allies after a heightened conflict between the South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: Activists protest against Turkey in New Delhi on May 16.

item.title: Trump Says India Offered to Cut US Tariffs But He’s in No Rush
item.description: President Donald Trump said that India has offered to cut all its tariffs on US goods but downplayed any sense of urgency to reach a trade agreement with the world’s fourth-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the White House in Washington in February. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/Bloomberg

item.title: Supreme Court Extends Halt of Trump Venezuelan Deportations
item.description: The US Supreme Court blocked the Trump administration from using a wartime law to send about 176 Venezuelans to a notorious Salvadoran prison, faulting the government for not giving the men adequate notice about its deportation plans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

item.title: Trump Returns to Washington Ready Deploy New Tariff Tactics
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Friday, White House correspondent Akayla Gardner delivers a roundup of the key news and events in politics, policy and economics that you need to know. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

item.title: Why Trump Is Targeting Harvard’s Funding and Tax-Exempt Status
item.description: President Donald Trump has been waging a campaign to pressure elite US colleges to make a wide range of policy changes, in what his administration has framed as an initiative to fight campus antisemitism and enforce civil rights protections.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Harvard Yard on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on April 16.

item.title: Chicago Taps EY to Close $1 Billion Gap as Trump Threatens Funds
item.description: Chicago is hiring Ernst & Young LLP to help the city slash costs and close budget gaps that are forecast to top $1 billion in each of the next two years.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh

media:content.media:description: The skyline of Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024. Chicago is delaying its $643 million bond sale that was expected to price last week amid volatility in the $4 trillion market for state and local bonds.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Fails in House Panel as GOP Splits on Cost
item.description: A key House committee on Friday failed to advance House Republicans’ massive tax-and-spending bill after hard-line conservatives bucked President Donald Trump and blocked the bill over cost concerns.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard, Tyler Kendall

media:content.media:description: UNITED STATES - MAY 16: Rep. Chip Roy, R-Texas, arrives for the House Budget Committee markup of the reconciliation bill in the Cannon House Office Building on Friday, May 16, 2025. (Bill Clark/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump’s Crypto Project Pushes Back on Senate Inquiry
item.description: Attorneys for Donald Trump’s World Liberty Financial crypto project pushed back against claims about potential conflicts of interest raised by the Democratic head of a Senate investigative subcommittee.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: The World Liberty Financial website arranged on a smartphone in New York, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 12, 2025. Chase Herro, co-founder of President Donald Trump's DeFi project, World Liberty Financial, said the platform plans on creating a strategic reserve with tokens bought.

item.title: Trump Puts Wealth Fund on Back Burner as Ambitions Hit Limits
item.description: President Donald Trump has put his plan to create a sovereign wealth fund on the back burner after three months of administration deliberations failed to offer the broad investment flexibility he seeks, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Marion Halftermeyer, Joe Deaux, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a cabinet meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 30, 2025. Trump blamed former President Joe Biden for weak economic data that sent stocks tumbling, arguing government data showed increased domestic investment signaled his tariff regime is working.

item.title: CFTC to Dwindle to Two Members After Goldsmith Romero Departure
item.description: The five-person Commodity Futures Trading Commission will soon be down to just two members, after Commissioner Christy Goldsmith Romero announced plans to leave the agency at the end of the month.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud

media:content.media:description: Christy Goldsmith Romero, nominee to be chair of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), speaks during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee nomination hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, July 11, 2024. As the Biden administration's pick to lead the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., Goldsmith Romero would face a different kind of cleanup after allegations of sexual harassment, discrimination and a toxic workplace rocked the agency.

item.title: Europe Waits to Find Out Where Trump Swerves to Next on Russia
item.description: European officials have no idea what President Donald Trump will say next about Russia’s war in Ukraine — or where that may leave them.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Natalia Drozdiak, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by the German Government Press Office, leaders of France, Germany, Poland and the UK joined Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, second from left, in a phone call with US President Donald Trump, in Tirana, Albania, on May 16.

item.title: Russia, Ukraine Discussed Truce, Prisoner Swap in Talks
item.description: The first direct talks between Russia and Ukraine in more than three years ended in Turkey with an agreement on an exchange of prisoners and discussions on a potential ceasefire, though no truce was announced.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Natalia Drozdiak, Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Hakan Fidan chairs a meeting with Russia and Ukraine at Dolmabahce Palace in Istanbul, on May 16.

item.title: SALT Republicans Signal $80,000 Cap Could Be on Table
item.description: Two New York Republicans signaled that the cap on the state and local tax deduction may rise to as much as $80,000 as GOP lawmakers from high-tax states demand a boost in exchange for their votes on President Donald Trump’s tax package.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Representative Nicole Malliotakis

item.title: Slovenia Calls on NATO to Expand Its Defense Spending Terms
item.description: Slovenia and several NATO member states are seeking ways to expand the definition of defense spending as they attempt to meet US calls to allocate more funds on security, the nation’s prime minister said.
item.dc:creator: Jan Bratanic

media:content.media:description: Robert Golob, Slovenia's prime minister, speaks to members of the media during the NATO Summit in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, July 10, 2024. President Joe Biden and NATO's 31 other leaders had hoped their summit would celebrate fresh unity against Russia's Vladimir Putin, send a warning to China and prove the alliance is as strong as ever in its 75th year, but the three days of pageantry will be overshadowed by domestic turmoil across the alliance.

item.title: Trump Threatens Iran Over Nuclear Offer Tehran Calls ‘Confusing’
item.description: President Donald Trump said Iran will face “something bad” if it doesn’t quickly accept a US proposal over its nuclear program, while officials in Tehran called the the US messaging “confusing and contradictory.”
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks to media on Air Force One as he departs Abu Dhabi on May 15.

item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Poland’s Presidential Vote Puts Tusk’s Reform Agenda at Stake
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s push to undo eight years of populist rule faces a reckoning just as other parts of Europe struggle to contain rising support for more conservative, nationalist forces.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Energy Tax Credit Fight Splits GOP in Snag for Speaker
item.description: Moderate House Republicans are lobbying House Speaker Mike Johnson to lessen cuts to several clean energy tax credits in the broad tax and spending bill prior to the GOP’s plans to bring it to the floor next week.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Jen Kiggans

item.title: Trump’s Aerospace Deals Were Big on Numbers and Slim on Details
item.description: US President Donald Trump ended his tour of the Middle East’s wealthiest countries touting new investments totaling a claimed $3.6 trillion — though upon closer inspection many of the deals appear inflated or recycled.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg sits to the left of US President Donal Trump and Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani (R) during a business deal signing ceremony at the Royal Palace in Doha, on May 14, 2025. Trump touched down at Hamad International Airport in Doha, with relations between the two governments in the spotlight over Qatar's offer to Trump of a $400 million luxury aircraft to serve as a new Air Force One and then pass into his personal use. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP) (Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Gulf States Embrace Trump’s New Vision of Middle East
item.description: At every stop on his just-ended tour, President Donald Trump’s words were music to the ears of his Saudi, Qatari and Emirati hosts.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Attendees wait to hear MBS and President Trump speak during a Saudi-US investment forum on May 13. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Ex-US Envoy to Ukraine Says She Resigned to Protest Trump Policy
item.description: The former US ambassador to Ukraine said she resigned in protest over President Donald Trump’s handling of the conflict with Russia and that she could no longer stand by while he pressured the government in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Bridget Brink Photographer: SAUL LOEB/AFP

item.title: Trump Berates Republicans to ‘Stop Talking,’ Pass Tax Cuts
item.description: President Donald Trump called on members of his party to unite behind his economic agenda in Congress, putting pressure on factions of lawmakers who are calling for last-minute changes to the legislation to drop their demands.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Tyler Kendall

media:content.media:description: ABU DHABI, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES - MAY 16: U.S. President Donald J. Trump speaks to media on Air Force One as he departs the Al Bateen Executive Airport on May 15, 2025, in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. Trump is on the fourth and final day of his visit to the Gulf to underscore the strategic partnership between the United States and regional allies including the UAE, focusing on security and economic collaboration. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Petro Shrugs Off US Move to Defund Chinese Projects in Colombia
item.description: President Gustavo Petro brushed off the US bid to block the financing of projects in Colombia being built by Chinese state companies as his administration moved to join a development bank backed by the Asian nation.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina, Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: A construction crew works on pillars for the Bogotá metro project Colombia’s capital in July 2024.
